decisions.rationale: Balance between encouraging ongoing participation and not punishing temporary absence. 2% allows someone to take a month off without catastrophic decay, but still incentivizes regular engagement.

alternatives_considered.rejected_because: Too harsh - people would lose significant Astris after short breaks
Too lenient - doesn't meaningfully encourage participation
Could lead to hoarding and disconnect between current contribution and voting power

decisions.impact: Affects token distribution fairness and participation incentives

decisions.rationale: Auctor represents civic voice/equality, so decay should be gentler than merit-based Astris. Quarterly decay ensures people who move away or become inactive don't retain permanent voting power, but allows for life circumstances.

alternatives_considered.rejected_because: Too frequent for a civic voice token - people have other responsibilities
Could lead to ghost voters who no longer participate in community

decisions.impact: Maintains fairness in civic voice while respecting life circumstances

decisions.rationale: Needed vector database for semantic search. ChromaDB offers good balance of features, performance, and ease of use. 768-dim model (all-mpnet-base-v2) provides good semantic understanding without excessive compute requirements.

alternatives_considered.rejected_because: More complex setup, heavier resource requirements
Lower quality semantic search, harder to capture nuance

decisions.impact: Foundation for all RAG functionality, affects search quality

decisions.rationale: Mimics CPU cache hierarchy - different access patterns need different storage. Hot (current session) in RAM for speed, warm (user profile) in JSON for simplicity, cold (all history) in ChromaDB for semantic search.

alternatives_considered.rejected_because: Would be slow for frequently accessed data like user profile
Can't do semantic search, would grow too large
Adds complexity, doesn't solve semantic search problem

decisions.impact: Defines how FAITHH stores and retrieves all information

decisions.decision: FAITHH is a thought partner, not just a search tool
decisions.rationale: Jonathan's core problem is maintaining project coherence when attention shifts. He doesn't need another search engine - he needs a system that remembers WHY projects matter and helps him pick up where he left off. This fundamentally changes development priorities from accuracy-first to synthesis-first.

alternatives_considered.rejected_because: Would be impressive but wouldn't solve the actual problem of losing context when switching projects
Jonathan doesn't need more task lists - he needs to understand the 'why' behind tasks

decisions.impact: Changes success metric from 'accurate answers' to 'maintains coherence across attention shifts'. Focus shifts to Level 3 synthesis, not just Level 1 recall.
